subject.name: Technical Writing
subject.description: Introduces students to the principles and practices of effective technical communication. Focuses on clarity, structure, and audience awareness in professional and scientific documents. Emphasizes written, verbal, and visual communication in engineering and technology contexts.
objectives: To understand the variety of structures used in technical documents
To convey clearly, cogently, and correctly through written media the technical aspects of a practice to audiences
To recognize and use verbal and technical elements necessary for successful scientific and technical communication
To work collaboratively and individually to research, analyze, and write about public debates regarding science and technology

units.title: Fundamentals of Technical Writing
topics: Need for clear and concise technical writing
Attributes and types of technical writing
Benefits of technical writing: technical, managerial, and general readers
Expressing versus impressing
Correct usage of grammar: noun, pronoun, verb, adjective, adverb, tense, and punctuation

units.title: Performing Technical Studies and Writing Strategies
topics: Types of technical studies and methodologies
Project proposal and report development
Gathering and analyzing background information
Designing test plans, performing experiments, and reporting results
Writing strategies: analysis of readers, purpose, and scope
Document options and report types
Technical content and presentation standards
Elements of writing style and effective illustration

units.title: Formal and Informal Technical Reports
topics: Structure of formal reports: outline, title, introduction, body, and conclusion
Writing procedures, describing processes, and presenting test results
Discussion and interpretation of findings
Components of informal reports: investigation reports, service work, action letters, and proposals
Elements of typical memo reports

units.title: Review, Editing, and Oral Presentation
topics: Types and methods of review and editing
Examples of reviews and editing methodology
Preparation and delivery of oral presentations
Use of visual aids and graphics
Techniques for maintaining writing skills and measuring report effectiveness

suggested_books: Engineers’ Guide to Technical Writing by Kenneth G. Budinski, ASM International
Handbook for Technical Writing by James H. Shelton, NTC Contemporary Press
The Technical Writer’s Handbook: Writing With Style and Clarity by Matt Young, University Science Books
A Guide to Technical Writing by T. A. Rickard, Franklin Classics
Technical Writing by S. Jayprakash, Himalaya Publishing House Pvt. Ltd.
Technical Writing by O. N. Pandey
